19501.name: Jam Doodle
19501.description:
One part art, one part communication. For two or more players.

Object: To describe a drawing composed of basic figures accurately enough that your partner can draw it.

You Need: Paper and pencil for each player. A small sketch pad works better than 8.5 x 11, but any paper will do.

There are two roles in Jam Doodle: creator/describer and drawer. During the game, you will take turns swapping roles. When you're the describer, choose a doodle and begin describing it to your partner. When you're the drawer, try to draw your partner's doodle as accurately as possible from the description.

When both of you agree that you're done, turn around and compare the doodle to the copy that was just drawn.

* If the copy is an accurate duplication of the original, then you've accomplished your goal. It's okay if the copy is drawn to a different scale, as long as the ratios between the objects are accurate.
* If the copy differs from the original, then take some time to discuss where it differs, why it differs, and what information could have made it come out differently.

Once you're done, swap roles and start again.

Several variants to the basic rules are available on the website as well.

Download the rules here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/92/jam-doodle

19502.name: Penguin's Night Out
19502.description:
A race game on an ever-changing field for 2 to 4 players

"You've kept your beak to the grindstone with a hard week of catching fish and keeping eggs warm. Now it's time to gather your friends together, group at your nest, then head into town to party the night away.

"Unfortunately there's only one dog sled available to go into town, so the first group that's ready to leave gets to ride in style, while everyone else has to walk. To complicate matters, local drilling is causing the ice to crack and shift unpredictably. The path that you take to get to your buddies may not be there on your way home. On top of that, the Polar Bear Gang has been making life tough, so you'll have to be super-sneaky if you need to go through their territory.

"Even so, you're not going to let these obstacles stop you. You deserve a break, and you'll be darned if you're going to make the long, cold, 60-mile hike to town on flipper. Be the first one to gather your buddies up and get home again and you'll be ready for a...

"Penguin's Night Out!"

Object: To be the first player to collect all of your buddies and return home on an ever-shifting playing field.

You Need:

* A set of double-six dominoes.
* A penguin pawn for each player. Assorted chess pieces work well.
* Two buddy tokens for each player. Pocket change is a good choice.
* Two six-sided dice.
* Paper and pencil.

You and your opponents take turns moving around the board (made up of dominoes) and altering the board. End your turn in your nest while carrying both of your buddy tokens to be the first group to get your dog sled into town and win the game. Yippee!

Download the rules here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/113/penguins-night-out

19503.name: Dungeon (ICP)
19503.description:
A dungeon-crawling card game for 2 to 4 players

Captured and incarcerated, your only goal is to escape the underground prison you find yourself in. As you search for the hidden route to freedom, you must overcome the underworld's hostile inhabitants and dangerously unstable passages.

Object: To escape from your underground prison, or be the last one alive.

You Need: At least one standard deck of playing cards with Jokers. A single deck will suffice for a 3 player game, but such a game will be extended and bloody! Two decks can be combined for 3 or more players, allowing a quicker and easier multiplayer game.

You and your opponent(s) take turns playing cards from your hand, trying to escape the dungeon while making it hard for the other players to escape. There are three basic card types in Dungeon:

1. Passages (the value cards, 2 through 10) represent the tunnels, passages, and rooms you must navigate to escape.
2. Creatures (the picture cards, Jack, Queen & King) represent creatures of the underworld.
3. Aces represent your finely honed adventuring skills.

If you escape the Dungeon or all of your opponents are dead, then you win!

Download the rules here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/392/dungeon-update

19504.name: Jackpot Las Vegas Game of Fun and Thrills
19504.description: A slot machine dice game. Each player contributes chips to the jackpot, then rolls special dice to determine the results. Additional rolls cost chips, and play continues as many rounds as desired.

19505.name: Catchphrase
19505.description:
In this game, each player has a common phrase, which the other players try to guess. You get clues about the phrase by spinning a spinner, and following the directions, which can include things like how many words are in the phrase, how many letters in a word, or what letters might make up the word. You track the answers on a board with spots for how many letters, what letters, etc.

Not to be confused with the party game, Catch Phrase!.

19506.name: Das Bierquartett
19506.description: 32 German brewers present their wares, with information in 5 categories, including alcohol content, year the brewery was founded, etc. The game is played according to the standard Quartett rules – each player plays out a card and each card’s entry in a particular category is compared – highest number wins (except for founding year, which is in reverse).

19508.description:
Description from the publisher:

Winter will be coming soon, and the forest creatures must look after their winter food supplies...
Gone are the days where all of them could find enough to eat without having to look very hard ... nowadays, they must fight for it!

In this card game, you'll take the side of hedgehogs, squirrels, rabbits or mice in the fight for the last food to be found in the forest. In the process, you can make use of all sorts of helpful items that people have "forgotten" in the woods. And there are lots of those items: an abandoned chainsaw, Cola cans, worn out, smelly shoes, illegally dumped oil containers and much more. If you're clever, you can also lure your opponents onto the roadway that people regularly travel through the woods.

Igels is a fast-paced, funny card game in which the winner is the player with the most food points at the end of the game.
19508.name: Igels: Das Kartenspiel

19509.name: Haselwurz und Bärenklau
19509.description:
From Spielbox:

In the game, the players build up a landscape with six-sided tiles (forest, rich meadows, lean meadows, farmland, lake, village and quarry). The players look for rare plants and animals at the corners of these tiles. There are four face-up animal or plant tiles which indicate which landscape types they must touch in order to be found there. Plants and animals, once found, are worth points.
The players travel as gnomes via dragonfly, badger, bird and grasshopper. The landscape determines which tiles can be crossed with which type of transportation. Players can only use the same type of transportation again after they have used all four at least once.

19510.name: Karlsson på Taket
19510.description:
Children´s game published in Sweden and themed on Karlsson på taket (Karlsson on the roof). The gameboard depicts Karlsson´s house and the apartment where the boy, Lillebror, lives.

Contents:
Gameboard
Die
7 figures
39 cards

Ages 5 and up

19511.name: Bosse Bildoktorn
19511.description:
Swedish game themed on a popular TV-series, Bosse Bildoktorn (`Bosse the Car Doctor´). Very enthusiastic car mechanic teaches the viewers just about everything in Do-It-Yourself. The game is basically roll, move and answer questions on cars, tourism in Sweden, entertainment, etc. Players may also buy motels and garages to make other players pay, Monopoly-style.

Contents:
Board
385 cards with 1925 questions
Some other cards
Players´ pieces
Dice
Motels
Garages
Money
Pencil
Rules

Ages 13 and up. Language: Swedish.

19512.description:
Vanished! Stolen! ... The eight ebony totems and the prestigious gold totem, vestiges of an ancient civilization, were stolen by Rastapopoulos from the ethnographic museum. Tintin and his companions set out at once to recover them. But the stolen copies of the totems are spread out around the world and confuse the tracks of the investigators. Only a "magic key" will make it possible to find the treasures of the museum.

Of the 20 ebony totems, 12 are real! Only the magic key will reveal them to you... collect as many of the Totems as possible, but avoid conflicts with Rastapopoulos the gangster. Character cards direct you in your investigation or help you to thwart the schemes of your adversaries. Brought into play at the end of the game, the gold totem must still be recovered for victory.

translated (badly) from rulebook and entry from "Club de Stratégie de Moissy-Cramayel

Translated from the Dutch box:
A breathtaking game full of adventures with Tin Tin and his friends.
Face Rastapopoulos in a duel and win the mysterious Totem Dhor.
But beware! 12 of the 20 Totems are traps! Only the magical cassette can point you in the right direction.

Gameplay information:
Every square on the board represents one of Tintin's adventures and contains a black totem pole. You have to use a magnet to learn if the totem is a good one or a trap. If the totem moves away from the magnet, it is a trap. If it pulls towards you it is one of the 8 good ones. Players check the totems individually and place it on the middle of the appropriate adventure square. This means the nature of this totem is known to one of the players. He must memorize all the totems he checked. In the second part (when all totems are known by one or more players), when a player starts an the adventure players have to tell the other players what status the totem has, if he is right he gets the totem. If he gets it wrong he loses a research point.

When all 8 good totems are found the golden Rastapopoulos totem is placed for the final adventure. When players cross Rastapopoulos himself they have to fight him (by a throw of the dice).

When a player loses all his points he has to start at the beginning of the board and receives 4 new points to re-enter the race until the golden totem is reached.
19512.name: Tintin et le Piège du Totem Dhor

19513.name: Labirynt Czarnoksiężnika
19513.description:
Labirynt Czarnoksiężnika (The Sorcerer's Labyrinth) is the first game published by Kuźnia Gier. Each player controls a group of heroes from four races (dwarves, the undead, wererats, wood elves), trapped in a maze by an evil warlock. The goal of the players is to break free from the maze by collecting crystals. During play the heroes will be fighting monsters and collecting various items. Only one team can escape.

The game contains the following components:

- 4 double-sided boards
- 12 character sheets
- 13 character pawns
- 30 plastic markers in two colors
- 144 tokens
- 2 reference sheets
- 2d6
- the rulebook

19515.name: Election
19515.description: Players move across a map of Europe to gain popularity for the upcoming European elections. Points are scored for completing secret goals indicated on different colored cards.

19516.name: Waarom? Daarom!
19516.description:
On your turn you draw a card and read the question out loud. The correct answer is also printed on the card. Questions range from absurd to very difficult. eg : "Why is a carrot orange and a tomato red?" or "What happens to the caffeine that 's extracted to create caffeine free coffee?"
Each player writes an answer in secret on a piece of paper. The player who read the question writes down the correct answer in his own words. Answers are gathered, shuffled and numbered. The answers are read out loud and every player votes on what he thinks is the correct answer. The other players get a point if they guess the correct answer or if someone thought his or her wrong answer was right.
The first player who reaches the end of the 20 step score track wins the game.

19518.name: McHale's Navy Game
19518.description: Each turn the player draws a card from the supply deck and moves one space. If he announces he has a pair or more, he is entitled to Bonus Moves. You may bluff announcing a pair, three of a kind or four of a kind. The other players may challenge and if the bluffer has the cards he make make the bonus moves and the challenger moves back 4 spaces. If the player is bluffing and doesn't have the cards, he moves back 4 spaces. In addition there are instruction cards that move all ships ahead and penalty instruction cards that move the player backwards. In addition there is a cardboard torpedo which can be fired to move ahead. The winner is the first player to cross the finish line.

19519.name: Famous 500 Mile Race Game
boardgamepublisher: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.
19519.description:
Each player chooses a car or group of cars he wishes to win.
Spin the spinner to move the 33 cars along the track. If you land on a square marked Crash or Mechanical Trouble, spin the spinner to see which car it affects and it is removed from the board. If a Pit Stop is indicated the car must move back 2 spaces. If more than 4 cars occupy certain spaces there is a crash. Otherwise if 4 cars occupy a space all other cars behind them must stop. The first car that crosses the finish line wins.

19520.name: Counter Punch
19520.description:
Counter Punch, designed for the real fight fan, is a game that combines the excitement and strategy of boxing. Counter Punch is a game where everyone has an equal chance to win. As in an actual boxing match, this card game requires strategy or you could find yourself on the seat of your pants or, even worse, KO'd!

Counter Punch is a 2 player card game. There are 49 cards total, on which appear numbers and punch words. Example: Jab-1, Body-2, Hook-3, Overhand-4, Uppercut-5, Combo-6 and Power Punch-7. The higher the number, the harder the punch.

Before each round of play, 12 cards are dealt to each player. The last player to win each trick, throws out the next card first. Whoever played the highest card wins the trick. After the end of each round (each has played their 12 cards), scoring is as follows:

6 to 6 = even round
7 to 5 = Out Pointed Opponent
8 to 4 = Opponent was Hurt
9 to 3 = Knocked Opponent Down
10 to 2 (or better) = Knockout (instant victory)
3 knockdowns in one bout = a Technical Knockout Victory

19521.description: This series of abstract games are played on a cloth banner with nicely polished stones. There are a total of seven different games. There is one solitaire game and the remaining six games are either for 2 players or 3 players. This game is packaged in a mailing tube. The contents include a cloth banner for the playing board, a rule book, a cloth bag with draw string, 15 finely polished stones and 1 six sided die.
19521.name: Stones: Seven Challenges of the Pharaohs

19522.name: Antikrundan
19522.description:
Themed on the popular Swedish TV show Antikrundan. Players bid on antiques, trying to estimate their true value. If you bid too high, you loose money. Players also may pick up old things at the flea-market. Some items may be fake. This is decided by experts at the end of the game. Money is also awarded for answering questions on antiques. Questions are multiple choice, so you need not be an expert to stand a chance.

Contents:
Gameboard
91 auction cards
129 question cards w/ 774 questions
60 value cards
20 flea-market cards
1 die
4 player’s pieces
money
rules

Ages 15 and up. Language: Swedish.

19523.name: Lilla snigel
19523.description:
Children´s game published in Sweden. Players are trying to reach the snail´s house in the middle of the board. When you turn a tile in your colour face-up you get one step closer to the house. Watch out for rocks and the bird.

The title, Little snail, is a song well-known to small children.

Wooden board, tile and die.

Ages 4 and up. Language independent.

boardgamehonor: 2005 Charles S. Roberts Best DTP-Produced Boardgame Nominee
19524.description:
Published in 2005 by BSO Games (DTP), the description is from the GMT website, when it was on their p500 list.

It's Turning Point, a game covering the pivotal battle of Freeman's Farm, at Saratoga. It features all the units, from Morgan's Rifles to the British grenadiers, and all the dense, wooded terrain you would normally expect, but in a way you've probably not seen before.

The game uses two decks of cards, one deck for each player to drive the game. Each player gets a certain number of his cards each turn, never his full deck, and his allotment is usually different (in terms of number and type) from his opponent. The cards are used to determine movement, combat, and special items, such as Indian Stealth, Counter-Attack, Rifle Fire, and Rapid Movement, among others. Players may play as many cards as they wish when it's their turn, using each card for only one of the possible three purposes. Play passes back and forth between players, until both players have used all their cards … and the Turn is over.

Turning Point is thus a game of card play and management, which unfolds on the map of Freeman's Farm, which uses squares, rather than hexes,. You're still moving units, trying to outflank, attacking with what you hope are better odds (since you don't know what cards your opponent will play, if any, and you never know what his final strength will be), and using your cards, and wits, to outplay your opponent.

Turning Point was a nominee in the Charles S. Roberts awards for Best DTP-Produced Boardgame (Charles S. Roberts Awards) for 2005.
19524.name: Turning Point

19525.name: Sibling Rivalry
19525.description:
Sibling Rivalry is a commissioned game from Richard Garfield for the game design textbook "Rules of Play", by Katie Salen and Eric Zimmerman.

Players are siblings trying to annoy each other. The game is played on two boards: the challenge board and the score track. By advancing a marker on the challenge board, you can score points on the score track. The first player to reach the end of the score track wins.

The heart of the game is a "push your luck" dice mechanism to advance on the challenge board. A player begins by rolling five dice, setting aside ones. Other numbers can be used to advance a pawn along one of five columns, representing Looks, Faces, Tickles, Ouchies, and Teases. After each roll, you can either stop or keep rolling. If you stop and your pawn is the most advanced pawn in that column, then you remove any pawn it passed. If it is not the most advanced, then you remove your pawn from the challenge board. If your pawn has not been removed from the board by your next turn, then you score points for it on the score track.

You can keep rolling dice to advance your pawn farther up the challenge board, but when you accumulate three or more ones, your parents have caught you picking on your sibling. Your turn ends and you lose points.

boardgamehonor: 2006 Årets Spill Best Family Game Nominee
2006 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee
2006 Tric Trac Nominee
19526.description: This is the second game in the 'Abenteuer Catan' (Catan Adventures) series that started with Candamir: The First Settlers. The theme of Elasund is based on the 'Die Siedler von Catan' novel written by Rebecca Gablé, itself based on the original The Settlers of Catan game. In Elasund, players compete and cooperate to build the premier city of Catan.
19526.name: Elasund: The First City
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGTG 60 - June 14, 2006 David Arnott Leftovers about Medici, Elasund (and Hacienda)
PGGK 042: Elasund: The First City

19527.name: Monopoly: Uniquely Singapore
19527.description: This game was introduced as part of the country's "Uniquely Singapore" tourism campaign. The key difference between this and the Monopoly - Singapore edition is that instead of street names as real estate for purchase, the new board features clusters like the tourist attraction cluster - Singapore Zoo, Jurong Bird Park etc, the shopping cluster - Marina Bay, Orchard Road, and the arts and entertainment cluster - Victoria Concert Hall, Esplanade, etc. The game also introduces two new tokens of local flavour - the Kucinta cat and the trishaw.

19528.name: Ballerina Card Game
19528.description:
Five games included using cards showing ballet positions.

The first (and most educational) requires the players to take the position shown on a card and the other players try to guess the name of the position.

Three rummy variants are also included, as well as a memory game.

19529.name: Deck of Dogs
19529.description:
Endorsed by the American Kennel Club. Seven suits of eight cards each, the suits being Herding, Working, Sporting, Non-Sporting, Toy, Terrier, and Hounds. Each card bears a picture of a different breed.

Two games are provided, one rummy variant and one Uno variant.

19530.name: Toot and Otto
19530.description:
From the manufacturer:

"A fun strategy game for older players who like tic-tac-toe and checkers... One player is TOOT and the other player is OTTO. Each takes six O's and six T's. The first player who spells his or her name - up, down, sideways, or on the diagonal - wins!

"A fill & find game for younger players. Simply drop all the T's and O's in the tower and when it's full, search for how many TOOT's and OTTO's you can discover!"

19531.name: Charoodles
19531.description:
From the manufacturer:

"Charoodles - the nonstop, fun props charades game!

"Can you act like a jellyfish using a foam square as a prop?

"Charoodles (sha-roo-dles) is an exciting new way to play charades using props. Players divide into teams and take turns acting out the items listed on one of the category cards. But there's a twist! Players MUST use props (a tube, a cup, a ball, and a square) to help them give clues. A 90-second timer makes the game fast paced and often downright hilarious."

19532.name: Baffle Gab
19532.description:
From the manufacturer:

"Gabby gives you 5 word cards to write a story. Add your own words and change the beginnings or endings on Gabby's words to create your story in one minute. Get all 5 Gabby words in the same sentence and double your Bone Bucks for the round! At the end of each round, read your story out loud and get lots of laughs. Risk your Bone Bucks when you challenge other players on the use of a Gabby word or their sentence structure. Be the Bone-yard Banker and pay out earned Bone Bucks after each round!"

19533.name: All About Harrisburg
19533.description: "Two to six players attempt to outsmart and out-luck each other in a riotous race ALL ABOUT TOWN. The first player to collect a total of eight (8) Travel Cards and return to his/her Residence is declared the winner."

19534.description:
First edition:

It is a development of the game system that appeared in VV #7, Abbeville 1940 and covers two other battles in the 1940 campaign, Hannut and Stonne. Both maps together take up one standard Vae Victis map. As with all Vae Victis games, counters need to be mounted and cut apart prior to play.

Vae Victis issue 63.

VV #63 also includes an ASL scenario and errata for the VV Las Navas de Tolosa, 1212 game.
19534.name: Blitzkrieg 1940: Hannut et Stonne

19535.name: Murder à la carte: Chinese Takeout
19535.description:
"The scene is a San Francisco townhouse filled with mementoes of Emily Boggs' days in China. The past has become present in the person of Anita Mumm. A long lost daughter? Or is she an impostor? Dinner turns deadly when Mrs Boggs' fortune cookie predicts no future.... for her."

The suspects :-

Chew Chow - Ms. Emily's cook and loyal servant for 25 years. His only humble request is to return to his homeland rich... and maybe at any cost.

Penny Sylan - A live-in nurse hired to care for Ms. Emily. Though she has a wonderful bedside manner, Penny has a history of losing her patients.

Axel Dent - Ms. Emily's chauffeur was driven crazy by her back seat driving. Did she push him to take the wrong turn on the road to life?

Lai Low - A young traditional Chinese maiden staying with Ms. Emily to learn western way. Lai has the face of innocence and purity but a heart filled with scorn.

Him Wong - A retired police detective from China who claims to have spent years searching for Ms. Emily's daughter. Has he accomplished the impossible or is he a master of illusion?

Anita Mumm - Ms. Emily's long-lost daughter... or is she? Anita bears a resemblance to the late Mr. Boggs, but is she really their missing heir or a clever con?

Contents:-

6 Invitations and envelopes to be sent to your guests
Character booklets for all 6 suspects, includes their roles and background information.
Cassette tape with an introduction, summary of events and the solution to the crime
Party planner booklet
6 secret clues
6 place cards

For six players Ages 12 and up.

19536.name: Toy Story 2 Cone Crossing Game
19536.description: Based on the scene in Disney's "Toy Story" where Buzz Lightyear and company race across a busy road while hiding under traffic cones to rescue Woody. In this game designed for ages 4 and up you first roll a die to determine how many action points you get on a turn. Then you have three choices move the cones (you and your opponents cones are identical so you better remember which cones are yours). Or you may move obstacles to impede the path of your opponents. Or you may send the truck down the street (sending any cone it hits back to "GO").

boardgamehonor: 2005 Charles S. Roberts Best DTP-Produced Boardgame Nominee
19537.description:
From the back of the game:

The Wars of the Roses (1453-1485) were the result of the struggle for the English crown between the Houses of Lancaster and York ... both descended from the Plantagenet line ... both with equal claim to the throne. By the end of the bloody struggle, both houses would be extinct and the crown grasped by the first of the Tudors.

Sun of York is a card game depicting the tactical battles fought between the two royal houses. Represented by the cards are all the day's major leaders, including King Henry VI (too weak a leader to maintain control of the kingdom), Margaret of Anjou (Henry's strong-willed and manipulative queen), King Edward IV (organizational genius and longest holder of the Crown), King Richard III (charismatic leader of questionable morals) and Richard Neville, Earl of Warwick (the "King Maker"). Troop cards include Levies, Longbowmen, Knights, Cavalry, and mercenaries from the Continent, among others. Terrain features and Special event cards are also included.

Every major engagement (and a few minor ones) is included in Sun of York, for a total of eighteen scenarios in all! Rules for randomly generated scenarios are included as is a campaign system allowing players to fight out the Wars to their bloody conclusion.

Components include 200 cards, two player aid sheets, and one sheet of 234 status markers.
[This is a desktop published game. Players are required to assemble all game components.]

Now also available (August 2011) through GMT Games as a boxed set!
19537.name: Sun of York
boardgamefamily: Dixie: American Civil War Card Game
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 58: Mike Nagel on Flying Colors and more
The Gaming Gang Episode 26: Conquest of Nerath, Keep Up the Fire, Space Empires 4X, and Sun of York
The Messy Game Room Episode 29

19538.name: Sporting Triangles
19538.description:
SPORTING TRIANGLES - ITV's Question and Answer game for all the family.

Now everybody can be part of the quick-fire question and answer fun of the top rated TV show. With 3,000 sporting questions to help and harass you it's a race around the triangular board for up to four players or teams. Those who use their sporting knowledge to best advantage and are the first to complete the 'sporting triangle' win the game.

Contents:

Game board
3,000 questions and answers
Scoring base and pegs
Four playing pieces
Die

19539.description:
From back of box:

What would you like to be when you grow up? A glamorous actress, a graceful ballerina, an out-of-this world pilot? Choose a career, then follow the path that leads to success. As you work your way toward your goal you may experience occasional setbacks, but don't be discouraged. the first player to fulfill her dream of an exciting career wins the game.

Basically, a simple spin-and-move game that has players collecting chits and working their way, ring by ring, towards the center of the board.
19539.name: Barbie: We Girls Can Do Anything

boardgamehonor: 2005 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Japanese Game Nominee
19540.description:
This a "tic-tac-toe" style game by the Japanese company Bandai. It features cute little figures which can be placed on some places of the board head-up and in some others head-down. The objective is to get three in a row, but there are some specific rules governing movement and placement.

The name of the game is pronounced as "shim-pay". It was named after the designer, Shimpei Takahashi.
19540.name: Simpei

19542.name: Funny Train Card Game
19542.description:
Object: Make a train with an engine, caboose, and 4 different animals.

Includes 34 cards plus 2 instruction cards.

19543.name: RAVE Master! Trading Card Game
19543.description:
Based on the mega Japanese hit mange RAVE Master that in Japan has spun off into an anime series and multiple video games as well.

Synopsis of story:
The Continent of Song is in chaos. The sinister secret society known as Demon Card is using the power of Dark Bring to destroy everything in their path. The only things capable of stopping Dark Bring are the Rave stones. Unfortunately, the Rave Stones were scattered around the globe in an explosion 50 years ago, so now they must be collected by the Rave Master in order to stop Dark Bring once and for all.

boardgameimplementation: Berserk: Tactical Card Game – War of Realms
19544.description:
In the distant world of Laar wandering armies, led by powerful magicians live a life of battle. For eons they fought for survival in this world, once scorched by fires of the Cataclysm. Now you have the chance to gather your own army and become the maker of your own fate. Perhaps, your path will shape the fate of Laar as well... In fierce battles your life and lives of your trusted armies will only depend on your skill of a strategist and a warlord. And then, when in the heat of battle you will once forget about your wounds, about the future and about the past - you will understand why this is not simply a game. It is Berserk.

Over 3000 different cards to collect, 14 different editions.

1. Battle of Realms (October 2003)
1.1. Equillibrium (expansion) (Spring 2004)

2. Fall of Darkness (Fall 2004)
2.1. Birth of Heroes (expansion) (Spring 2005)

3. Will of the Temple (Fall 2005)
3.1. Grip of Chaos (expansion) (Winter 2005)
3.2. Hour of Monsters (expansion) (Spring 2006)

4. Hammer of Time (Fall 2006)

5. Silent Watch (Spring 2007)

6. Rage of Gods (Fall 2007)

7. Nemesis Angels (Spring 2008)

8. Interworld (Fall 2008)
8.1. Lost Squadron (expansion) (Winter 2008)

9. Black Wings (Spring 2009)

10. Dertakh's Secret (Fall of 2009)

11. Eclipse (December of 2009)

12. Vengeance (May of 2010)

13. Arhaal's Path (October of 2010)

14. Cataclysm (March of 2011)

15. Angheim (August of 2011)

[Special - duel deck] Orenkholm's Fate

16. Flying Fortress (October 2011)

[Special - duel deck] Angels and Demons

[Special - collector's pack] Promo Dragons 2012

17. Shaken Earth (March 2012)

[Special - duel deck] Curse of Blackwood

18. Demise of Machines (August 2012)

19. Voice of Laar (February 2013)
19544.name: Berserk: Trading Card Game

19545.name: Kakapo Rescue
19545.description:
From box:
Five Kakapo are in danger! In this game you team up and go into the wilderness to find the Kakapo and bring them back to base camp. Trap any predators that block your way and share equipment for the Kakapo Rescue. Kakapo are endangered New Zealand flightless Parrots.

This game has a concept license from Jim Deacove.

19546.name: The Share Game
19546.description:
The object of the game is to win as much as possible by buying and selling shares.
Brief description: Players are each given oil shares, industrial shares, mining shares and money - 1000 of each.
The first player takes a telegram from the top of pile and reads it to himself and places it face down on the table in front of him. he then throws the two dice at the same time and moves the correct share marker to a higher or lower price and follows any printed instructions there.
He may use his telegram at this point or hold to a later point in the game. To present it he turns it face upwards and the share marker to which it applies is then moved to a higher or lower price as indicated by telegram.
Shares may then be bought or sold by any player at the value indicated.
Then once players have bought or sold play continues by the next player picking up a telegram.

When the last telegram is taken from the pack, the dice are thrown for the last time. Each player is then, in turn given one chance to present any telegrams still held.

Note: One die is chosen as the number 1 die. This die determines which share type rises or falls, according to the table printed on the board and box. The other die shows the amount of fluctuation. For example if number 1 die shows 3 and number 2 die shows 6 the price of mining shares will fall 6 points.
Table as below:
No 1 dice
1. Industrials fall
2. Oils fall
3. Mining falls
4 Industrial rise
5. Oils rise
6. Mining Rises

19547.name: E.S.P.
19547.description:
From the publisher's site:

E.S.P. is a game for two players, powerful ESPer (person gifted with mental powers).

Five dice are rolled and put as a prize. Players put and move multipliers played hidden near these dice, struggling to match on their side their best tiles with the highest rolls, in order to gain victory points.

During each round, after the initial placement, you can use five special mental power in order to manipulate dice and multipliers: your goal is both to increase your score and to prevent your opponent in doing the same.

Each round may be either very quick or slow because of long reasoning; the ESPer winning three games will be the winner.

This game was available in the free web magazine GiocAreA OnLine (former partner of daVinci Editrice) as a promotional tool.

19548.name: Sexual Secrets
19548.description:
From the back of the box:

HIS:
The first time I touched a naked woman I....
On a scale of 1 to 10, I think my buns are...
When I get drunk, the sex gets...

HERS:
The thought of making love to two men at the same time
really makes me...
When I finally lost my virginity, I was...
The excuse I most often use for not making love is...

These are examples of sexual secrets; tasty little tidbits from deep within your very own wealth of intimate personal experiences. Do you dare confess your innermost confidences to other players or make up wild fantasies they might believe?

Includes 36 voting cards, 3 dice (1 red, 1 white, 1 black), 1 male confessions booklet, 1 female confession booklet, 1 scorepad, and original instructions. The back of the box mentions something about "432 sexual secrets", but the instructions do not list any such thing so I am taking it to be a misprint as even the picture on the back does not show anything that is not already present.

19549.name: Pegged Out
19549.description:
From the packaging:

"Socially interactive game for everyone.

Simple Rules, easy to learn and fun to play

Totally self-contained, easily transported. Can be played virtually anywhere.

Ideal for parties, family get-togethers, or when you just want to have fun!"

"The objective of the game is to lose all your pegs and 'Peg Out' before anyone else. Each player starts with 10 pegs which must be shown at all times.








To 'Peg Out' and win you must place your last 'Live Peg' down the 6 hole."

By rolling dice, the players determine which holes they are able to place their pegs in this turn. holes 1-5 are narrow, and a ridge around the peg means the pegs rest in the hole. the sixth hole is larger, allowing the pegs to pass through. the aim is to get all the pegs out of your hand, however the last peg must go down the 6 hole.

Game components:


Plastic tub with Lid containing the six 'peg holes'.
100 pegs (All one colour - though three colours available)
2 Dice

19550.name: The Rooster Coop
19550.description: The Rooster coop is a game where the players try to collect their family of chickens. It is done by moving the marker on the board and by sliding the tiles and by that changing their position. The rules are very simple that can be explained in a few minutes, but wining the game is a bit more tricky. The players try to collect their chickens, but at the same time, can try preventing other players from collecting their chickens by changing the positions of the tiles. Fun game for all the family.

19551.name: Six Points College Football
19551.description: Six Points (as its name implies) is a college football board game. Each team is represented by a series of tables representing rush and pass defense, special teams, all facets of the offense, and some miscellaneous tables. Results are obtained by having the offense pick a player and a play (pass or run). The offense rolls a die or dice for a result. The defense then rolls on the appropriate table to modify the result. Optional rules add defensive play calling to the game. Seasons are known to exist from 1975 through 1981.

19552.description:
The Penny Arcade cards for the Universal Fighting System.

From the website:

"Choose your fighter from the mega-hit webcomic Penny Arcade: the capricious prankster, Gabe, or the malevolent genius, Tycho. This February grab the Penny Arcade Card Game from Sabertooth Games and re-enact their ferocious - and comic - battle for the watch. Sit down with a friend, choose your character, and play out the hilarious battle with attacks and moves inspired by the comic. The card game comes with two sixty card decks in high quality deck boxes, containing everything you need to sit down and play immediately. The cards feature all new art and flavor text from the creators of the webcomic, Mike Krahulik and Jerry Holkins. The Penny Arcade Card Game is also fully compatible, and tournament legal, with the Universal Fighting System (UFS) Collectible Card Game by Sabertooth Games, allowing you to face Gabe and Tycho off against an ever expanding army of your favorite fighter game characters."
19552.name: Universal Fighting System: Penny Arcade

19553.name: Kave Kapers
19553.description: Object of game is to the first spelunker to successfully map a cave. The arrangement of the boards create a different each time you play it. Players must avoid water hazards, rock falls, and low passages.

19554.name: Plext
19554.description:
from the rule book:

Plext: The Game of Few Words

The object of Plext is to find as few words as possible that contain, in order, the 14 letter dice. Make a low bid to prove your vocabulary skills. If you prove your bid is correct, you score points! If you are not correct, the next lowest bidder will have a chance at the points. After 8 rounds the player who has the most points wins!

19555.name: COSMIC Super Business
19555.description:
This game published in Poland in the years of economic crisis (last years of real socialism in central-eastern Europe) is clearly a somewhat modified clone of Monopoly. The players buy rights to colonize planets (streets) and build their bases (houses) and planetary colonies (hotels).

The differences between this game and Monopoly are:
- There are 9 not 10 areas in a row of the board thus there are 2 systems with 3 planets and 6 systems with 2 planets;
- There is no auction if a player does not want to buy a planet;
- There are no parallels to railway stations and power plants. Instead there are mining licenses (for magnetites, platinum, diamonds and uranium) and players may build mines on appropriate areas.There are also 3 transportation bases and players may build communication lines there.

19556.name: Dodeca Baseball Game
19556.description:
"The new and superior baseball game for fans of all ages." Each of the 2 players of the game is the manager of a team. His line-up may consist of players from his favorite Major League team or fictitious players. Each line-up of 9 players must, at all times, consist of 3 players designated as "good hitters" (blue 12-sided die), 4 players designated as "fair hitters" (red 12-sided die), and 2 designated as "weak hitters" (yellow 12-sided die). Two of the nine players should, also, be designated as "fast runners".

White die = scoring of the play
Blue die = good hitter
Red die = fair hitter
Yellow die = weak hitter
Brown die = scoring for sacrifice or hit-and-run
Green die = stolen base

19557.name: Old Mummy
19557.description:
(From the website)
WATCH OUT FOR OLD MUMMY!
Learn about ancient Egypt as you play fun card games in the style of "Old Maid" and "Concentration." Collect ancient treasures but don't get caught with the "Old Mummy" card! The game comes in a keepsake tin box and includes a full-color guide describing the gods, goddesses, symbols and beliefs of the ancient Egyptians.

Discover:

Who swallowed the sun each evening and gave birth to it each morning?
Why did the ancient Egyptians believe gold was the "flesh of the gods"?
What symbol was painted on coffins so the dead could see out onto the land of the living?

47 playing cards and a guide come in a fun tin box in the shape of a sarcophagus.

19558.name: Spellbinding
19558.description:
Spellbinding is a word game where the objective is to successfully identify a scrambled word while in the center space on the board and controlling the dice. The board consists of three concentric circles, divided into spaces, and a large center space.

When a player is in control of the dice, the player to his right is the SPELLBINDER. The SPELLBINDER is the game's arbiter. His duties are as follows: he selects a card from the deck; he scrambles the letters of a word on the card, which is indicated by the board or the second die; he presents that scrambled word; he determines who is the first to correctly identify the word (and whether a tie has taken place). The other players have one minute to identify the word. The first to identify the word gains (or keeps) control of the dice.
If no player correctly identifies the word, play continues to the left.

This process continues until a winner is determined.

19559.name: Enigmako
19559.description: Some criminals are hidden in the city. You're an agent who have mission to establish portraits of theses criminals. After ending this portraits, you compare it to the criminals files at the police station, than you need to catch him and bring him to jail.

19560.name: Zathura: Adventure is Waiting
19560.description: Based on the movie, players race to reach the planet Zathura. The game is a replica of the one in the film in many ways, incorporating a turn key which produces game cards, a robot which is moved along the board to thwart player progress, and a house puzzle which comes apart.

19561.name: Hot Money
19561.description:
From the instruction book:

"hot money... Will you be a saint or sinner?

The object of the game is to become the first player to reach THE TOP. To get there you must make millions of $$$, run up hundreds of thousands in debt, and earn a glowing reputation while surviving all the dirty tricks and delaying tactics your opponents play against you.

There are two levels of play:
The Daily Grind (the outer board) where you must earn your fortune in Cold Cash and/or in Hot Money.
and
High Society (the inner board) where you earn your reputation by purchasing the Keys to Success"

Hot Money is a roll and move game that uses two currencies, cold cash and hot money. Hot money comes from various illicit activities, and must be laundered into cold cash before a player can enter High Society

19562.name: Yipes!
19562.description:
A pop-o-matic game where players race to be the first to reach the LABORATORY, become the MONSTER and then chase the other players back to the start, trying to "eat" them on the way. The other players try to flee the MONSTER and safely reach the ENTRANCE SPACE.

Points are scored for becoming the MONSTER, reaching the ENTRANCE SPACE without being eaten and for being eaten (for good taste!). The player with the most points after 3 rounds is the winner.

19563.name: Snap Judgment
19563.description: What do the pictures have in common? You be the judge! Players race, all at once, to find picture cards with common traits. Things that are made of wood! Things that start with the letter C! Something found in a bedroom! Make "Snap Judgments" because it's speed that wins the game!

19564.name: Chikara
19564.description:
Chikara is a strategy game for two players. Each player has 26 sticks of one colour and plays from behind a black defensive line towards the opponent's line. The winner is the player who can first place a stick horizontally on the opponent's defensive line, with that winning stick being untouched by any opposing stick.

Sticks are removed when they touch an opponent's playing piece. Extra moves can be achieve through the use of reserve sticks held within strongholds. Attack is the best form of defense.

boardgamehonor: 1995 Mensa Select Winner
19565.description:
Each player or team has a number of magnetic wheels with letters on them. Players rotate, exchange, or trade their letter-wheels in an attempt to form the greatest number of high-scoring words. The game also includes rules for solitaire play.

1995 Mensa Select
19565.name: Word Spin Scramble

19566.name: Alagar XVI
19566.description: A checkers type game, using the standard chess type board. Pieces range with values 1 - 4, and the goal is to capture opponents pieces to total exactly 16 points. Pieces only move the value on the piece in straight lines, and capture by landing directly on the opponents piece.

19567.name: Quipto
19567.description: Game is a rummy type word card game. At the beginning of your turn, draw a card from the discard pile or top of deck. If you draw more than 1 from the discard pile, the last/bottom card must be played/melded in a word. With your hand of cards, you can create words or steal words from other players by adding onto the beginning or ending of their word.

19568.name: Corner the Market: Buy and Sell – With Play Money
boardgameversion: Kids playing game on boxtop edition
19568.description: Move around the board by the throw of the dice. Follow instructions on the board. If you enter Commodity Pit, you buy and sell contracts in order to get a corner on the market. If you land on a Buy square in the Pit you must buy at least one contract of that commodity. If you stop on a Sell square you must sell at least one contract of that commodity. If you land on a Swap square you must trade at least one contract with the player on your left. If you land on open trading you must buy, sell or trade one contract. If you do not complete the transaction then you must pay a fine. Game lasts a year of seasons, the player with the most assets wins.

19569.name: Turn the Tables Checkers
19569.description:
Checkers with a new twist!

The board is a hex composed of knobs with five knobs per side. There are four disks embedded in the play field with seven knobs on them, and the disks rotate. Each player has 12 checkers that fit over the knobs. Players move forward (only) and capture on hex diagonals like checkers. If a player has a checker on a turntable, they may turn it as far as they like in lieu of moving a checker.

You win by capturing all your opponent's pieces, just like...you guessed it...checkers.

19570.name: Tournament Golf
19570.description:
"It's Just Like Golf...Without the Walking"

The double-sided board is an overhead view of all 18 holes of the "Green Valley Country Club" (6760 yards, par 71), with greens, traps, rough, woods, and hazards. The board is also ruled off in squares, with each square 20 yards per side on the scale of the holes.

There are 14 dice representing four woods, eight irons, a wedge and a putter. These have various ranges (in yards)appropriate for the club printed on the faces. Another die called the "directional die" has either "hook" or "slice" and a yardage on each side.

Players hit their ball (represented by a colored tee) by announcing the direction they're hitting - one of the eight cardinal points - and rolling the directional die and the die for the club they're using. The new ball positioned using the die values and the grid. There are various rules restricting club use depending on the type of landscape you're hiting from. Once you're on the green there's no direction to worry about, just range and the odds on putter die.
The manufacturing quality of the game is very good, almost extravagant. The box is hefty, there's a nice cork-lined plastic holder for the dice, a pad of score cards, and large cards printed with golf terms, club ranges, and even golf etiquette ("Replace divots.").

19571.name: The Sudoku Game
19571.description:
Players must complete a partially filled number grid so that each column, row and square includes the numbers 1 to 9 but, only once in each!

The Sudoku Game delivers an exciting added dimension - not only can you play by yourself but, up to 4 players can play, solving the same puzzles simultaneously. Each player has their own set of the same 100 puzzles varying in difficulty from “Junior” to “Samurai”.
You can also choose from several gameplay variants: “Taimu” (Beat the Clock); “Ichiban” (First to Finish); and “Hinto” (Reveal) where players can choose to obtain clues in exchange for a points deduction.
In any variant, a player having completed the puzzle can call “Sudoku!” But players need to be wary of calling “Sudoku!” too soon as an incorrect solution will result in a points penalty.
In addition to 4 sets of 100 puzzles, the game incorporates a timer, solutions and 3 sets of clues (revealing corners, top lines and bottom lines, for the “Hinto” game variant).

19572.name: Touristo
19572.description:
Touristo
The Board Game of Singapore

From the rules:
"TOURISTO is a board game for two or more players. The play consists of getting to know some of the interesting places in Singapore, collecting as many token points as possible and escaping the multifarious pitfalls that are intricately simulated in the pot luck cards. Each player competes for the highest token value and he can strategize and take advantage by using his discretion wisely. The players can also have great fun and laughter with the creative catch-phrases that are used to portray the interesting places."

This game was obviously targeted at the tourist market. It is small, portable and features tourist destinations in Singapore, some of which are no longer around. References to the defunct Van Kleef Aquarium and Bukit Turf Club date the game to the 1980s or early 1990s.

It features a Monopoly style board with pictures of the tourist attractions on the spaces. There are 'Pot Luck' cards that act like chance cards, and token cards with point values that the players are trying to collect. Player's pieces feature a tiny Merlion's head.

19573.name: Jumping Pixies
19573.description: Using wooden seesaws, player try to make their pixies jump in holes of the player's color.

19574.name: Touristen-Nepp
19574.description:
Touristen-Nepp (The word means taking 'easy' money from tourists) let 3-8 plays have the 'holiday of their life'.
On a map you have to buy the right equipment to have a good holiday, boots for nature, sunglasses for the beach and 'something to be saved' for the sexual experience. And all is in the game as material, small plastic cars, small boots, small sunglasses and also, umm!!, the 'other things' ;-).

boardgamehonor: 1991 Mensa Select Winner
19575.name: Lapis
19575.description:
A game of LAPIS consists of ten rounds. Five rounds are for people categories, and five are for place categories. For each of the two categories, there is a spinner which helps randomly select a subgroup of each category. Five cards, each with a letter on it, are then dealt face up. Each player has ninety seconds to come up with the name of a person or place which includes as many of the five letters as possible.

1991 Mensa Select

19576.name: Mind the Gap
19576.description:
The theme of this game involves a tour of London with stops to see the sights, eat, enjoy the nightlife, and of course shop. For over 900 years ravens have patrolled the Tower of London. According to legend, if the Raven's ever leave, London will fall. The objective is to return the Ravens to the Tower of London.

Mind the Gap is a board game for 2-6 players ages 8 and up. The board consists of photographs of famous London attractions. Movement is determined by rolling dice and moving along a track representing different locations in London. There are cards used in the game providing information/trivia about London and parts of British life. These cards also affect game play by causing players to lose turns, switch places with other players, etc.

19577.description:
Cranium New York Booster Pack is a 45-card expansion to Cranium. It was created to raise money for the September 11th Fund. All cards pertain to New York City in some way, requiring players to impersonate famous New Yorkers, remember New York history, and draw and sculpt New York landmarks. The set contains 12 Star Performer cards and 11 cards each in the Creative Cat, Data Head, and Word Worm categories.

Expands:

Cranium
19577.name: Cranium New York Booster Pack

19578.name: Scene It? Harry Potter
19578.description:
All aboard the Hogwarts Express! Test your knowledge of one of the world's most famous wizards with film clips, puzzlers, and questions based on the Harry Potter movies. How much do you really know about Quidditch, Transfiguration, or the Dark Arts? You'll find out as you race your friends around the board.

Fun for wizards and muggles! You don't have to be a 5th year at Hogwarts to do well at Scene It?: Harry Potter. On-screen challenges test your powers of observation, word play and puzzle-solving skills, so even if you don't know the first thing about how to brew a Polyjuice Potion, you'll still have a great time playing Scene It?: Harry Potter.

You may well remember The Monster Book of Monsters, but do you remember how many eyes it has? Don't know? Don't worry! You'll see for yourself in the film clip!

Think you know how to tackle Boggarts and Basilisk, Dementors and dragons? Let Scene It?: Harry Potter put your Harry Potter film knowledge to the ultimate test!

Includes
· 1 Game DVD
· 1 Flextime Game Board
· 1 Six-sided Numbered Die
· 1 Eight-sided Category Die
· 4 Category Reference Cards
· 4 Metal Tokens
· 30 House Points Cards
· 160 Question Cards
· 1 Instruction Sheet

19579.name: Pit-Witz
19579.description:
Pit-Witz is an abstract strategy game system made in Singapore. The rules that come with the set describe 9 games that may be played with the set.

In the basic game of Pit-Witz, each player has 8 pieces and tries to get them from his corner to the opposite corner. The board is like a cross-word grid and pieces move like chess rooks. In making a move, the pieces have to move all the way down a corridor, until they encounter a dark square or another piece. Other games add the use of dice and money (called witzers).

The names of the other games are:
Jet-Witz
Banditz
Dice-Witz
Plus-Witz
Haggle-Witz
Stomp-Witz (also known as Beetles)
Claim-Witz
Morlocks

19580.name: Maze
19580.description:
Maze - A Maze Building Strategy Game For Two

The object of Maze is to construct a maze with as few tiles as possible, and to move your pawn through it from Start to Finish.

Each player starts with their Start/Finish tile on the table. Each turn, the player rolls a pair of dice. That player will then choose 2 out of the 3 options to perform, and allocates one of the rolled dice to each of those options. The options are:

Option 1: The player turns tile face up from a face down stack, until the number of face up tiles matches the number on the chosen die.

Option 2: The player chooses the number of tiles indicated by the die, and adds those tiles to their existing maze.

Option 3: The player advances their pawn through their maze as many squares (there are 2 squares per tile) as the die indicates.

The tiles have various configurations of bold lines around certain edges, indicating walls of the maze. When the maze is completed, it must be fully enclosed by the border, and all squares must be reachable by the pawn.

The round ends when a player has completed their maze and has moved the pawn from the Start to the Finish, entering Finish with an exact die roll. Alternatively, a round can end when both players have run out of tiles, and one of them has reached the end of their incomplete maze. Scores are tallied using various factors (number of squares in the maze, number of squares needed to complete the maze, number of squares the pawn needs to travel to reach the Finish, number of squares on unused face up tiles), and low score wins the round.

Rules are also included for variants to adjust the difficulty of the game.

(C) The Game Works, Inc. 1983

19581.name: Crossword Challenge
19581.description:
From the box:
Crossword Challenge gives you all the fun of a regular crossword as well as the chance to compete with your friends or family. Each player or team has a pad of blank crosswords. The "Cluemaster reads a clue and the first person to grab the Gizmo has the opportunity to answer.
The result is a hilarious grab for the Gizmo to make sure you answer first and get the points.
There are 40 puzzles in the book with varying degrees of difficulty.

Contents include: game board, gizmo (small soft plastic toy), 1 clue book, 5 crossword playing pads, 5 pawns, 5 pencils.

19582.name: Jumping to Conclusions
19582.description:
Object of the game: Place the cards face down and the counters in the center of the players. It is useful to play the game in sessions, by breaking the pack into two or three roughly equal parts. Keep the bottom card last.
The first player reads the clues on the first card to the other players, starting with the points at the top. The other players may try to answer at any time, without awaiting turns, but each player is allowed only one answer per clue. Where two or more players give the same answer together only the first is counted. Players may pass instead of answering that clue.
a correct answer wins the points indicated for that clue. Players pick up counters for their points. An incorrect answer loses five points.
Players take turns round to read the clues. Highest score after the last card is the winner.

19583.name: Tengamo
19583.description:
Tengamo offers four different games that can be played in this collectible magnet game. Game packs come with 6 random characters magnets (of 60 current) and a steel marble.

In "Roller Ball", each player tosses the same number of pieces onto the playing surface. Players then take turns rolling their steel balls to collect opponents until all pieces have been captured. Pieces have different point values, and the player with the most points wins.

In "Magnetic Pull", one game piece is placed in the center of the playing surface, and each player uses the magnetic properties of another Tengamo piece to try to drag the center piece to their side of the table. Pieces are placed in the game by both players until all have been used and collected. The one who has attracted the most pieces to their side wins.

"Stack and Build" allows players to create different shapes and images with pieces.

"Fridge Throw" can be played one of two ways. Players can throw Tengamo pieces on metal objects, such as the refrigerator, and try to connect without touching their opponents' pieces, or they can throw their pieces at the object and try to hit their opponents' pieces.

19584.name: Check Lines
19584.description: A two player game using an asymmetric board. Each player has five pieces and to win must be the first to position these so that they have two straight lines, both of three men (i.e. one piece must be used in both lines)

19585.name: Capital Talouspeli
19585.description:
Capital Talouspeli (economy game) is a Finnish Monopoly-like economy game manufactured by Nelostuote Oy.

From the box (translated from Finnish):
"Make business in stock markets or gamble with savings and interests.
As a real estate agent you buy and build estates and make money with them. As an investor you buy stocks, gain power for general meetings, or maybe you just do some cornering.
To win the game you must have right profile, strategy and tactics, but luck is involved in both good and bad. There are limitless number of player roles. You can thrive in many ways, as in real life.
When necessary, you have to change your chosen tactics and strategy. Inherited assets and lottery prizes can make surprising changes in the game. Wealthy players may buy their very own jet plane and fly around the world from business to business. Illegal businesses may sound nice, but risks are great.
Your game doesn't end in bankruptcy! After the debt restructuring it's still possible for you to win the game. The game may even be used to educate company management.
Have fun while developing your strategical, tactical and psychological skills.

19586.name: Tai Chi
19586.description:
In Tai Chi, each player has a Yin and a Yang token, which they attempt to guide to meet at the center of their score track by playing numeric cards that move the token one direction or the other.

Cards are played face down, and three from your hand of five are be played to move either of your own two tokens or your opponent's before revealing and resolving scores.

If a token lands at the center point, it may only be dislodged by a pair of identical cards being played on it.

Did your opponent just place a card on your track to move you away, or did he play a zero to bluff you into counteraction?

19587.description:
THE BABIES AND THE BEASTS

(VE #8)
VE #8, The Babies and the Beasts.

VE #8 allows you to add 5 new German vehicles to Avalon Hill's Up Front

* Goliath - A radio controlled tankette. You move it up to an obstacle. You ignite the 85 kg. bomb. You have no more Goliath, but you also have no more obstacle.
* Borgward - A radio controlled tankette. You move it up to an obstacle. You tell it to drop its charge. You move it away. Boom!
* Wanze (AKA: Bedbug, AKA: Borgward B IV Ausfuhring mit Raketenpanzerbuchse 54) - At the end of the war the Borgwards were not too useful since they were offensive weapons. So, 50 were re-equipped with 6 mounted panzerfausts each, so they could be used by the Volksturm (militia) as an anti-tank shotgun.
* Maus I - This Panzer VIII was never finished. This is the first proto-type that was fitted with only a dummy turret for trials. It has no bang. But, it is very tough and makes a nice mobile fort.
* Maus II - This is the second prototype of the Panzer VIII. It was armed with the same gun as the Jagdtiger and died defending its factory.

Besides the new units, VE #8 includes the rules for their use, new scenarios for each of them, a chart to incorporate them in DYO scenarios, and new terrain cards as called for in the new scenarios.

Expands:

Up Front
19587.name: The Babies and the Beasts

19589.description:
SWORD OF THE BALKANS

(Bosnian Muslim Hanjar (Sword) Division)

This set of additional cards allows you to add troops from the Bosnian Muslim Hanjar (Sword) Division to your Avalon Hill's Up Front game. Twenty thousand such troops were raised by the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem to help the Germans keep order in the Independent State of Croatia (ISC) during World war II.

To enhance play in your games, you get:


Background material about the troops and the theater of war
Instructions on how to integrate them into your current scenarios
New troop cards on very heavy card stock.
Looting/Jihad card


Expands:

Up Front
19589.name: Sword of the Balkans

19590.description:
VAIPA QUARTERLY

(Issue #3, The Polish Never Quit!)

VAIPA QUARTERLY, issue #3.

"For two decades after WWI Poles drank the sweet elixir of freedom. But envious neighbors saw them not as a country, but as a prize. Finally, the storm clouds broke and armies from East and West marched into Poland.
The Poles fought hard for their country. For six long years they fought. They fought in Poland, they fought in France, they fought in Norway, they fought in Britain, they fought in North Africa, they fought in Italy, they fought in Russia, and finally, they fought in Germany, all the way into Berlin and the Brandenburg Gate. They fought in the air, they fought on the seas, they fought on the land, and they fought behind enemy lines.
They had hoped that their unwavering opposition to the Axis would earn them the right to freedom after the war. Their motto was, "We don't ask for freedom. We fight for freedom!" However, only one of their foes was conquered. The other was now master of Eastern Europe. It would be four more decades until the Polish people would taste that sweet elixir again."

Contents:

* The Polish Anvil (1939)
* In The Frog Pond (1940)
* In Limey Land (1941-1945)
* The Polish Comrades (1943-19454)
* The Warsaw Ghetto (1943)
* The Home Army (1945)
* Warsaw's Warriors (An Up Front© Variant)

including:

* The magazine
* (Insert) 93 Uncut Character cards
o 1939 Polish Infantry
o 1939 Polish Cavalry
o 1939 Polish Airborne
o 1943 Warsaw Ghetto
o 1943-1945 Home Army
* (Insert) 76 Uncut Vehicle cards
o 1939 Polish
+ AFV's
+ Soft Targets
+ Rail Cars
o 1939 German
+ AFV's
+ Soft Targets
o 1944 Polish (Warsaw Uprising captured and homemade vehicles (Chwat, Magda, Kubus, etc.))
* (Insert) 45 mounted game counters, already separated

The variant includes rules for 10 Polish armies (1939 Polish Infantry, 1939 Polish Militia, 1939 Polish Cavalry, 1939 Polish Airborne, 1940 Polish/French Infantry, 1941-1945 Polish/British Infantry, 1944-1945 Polish/British Airborne, 1943-1945 Polish/Russian Infantry, 1943 Polish/Jewish Warsaw Ghetto Infantry, and 1944-1945 Polish Home Army Warsaw Uprising Infantry/Partisans), spreadsheets (like in Desert War) showing which cards to use for the original scenarios, partisan scenarios, and new 2-player, 3-player, and solo scenarios. Note: You will need Avalon Hill's Up Front© game to use this variant. With the original Up Front© game, you will be able to play over 75% of these scenarios. For some, you will need Avalon Hill's Banzai©, Avalon Hill's Desert War©, and VAIPA's The Fanatics©.
19590.name: The Polish Never Quit!

19591.description:
During the hunting seasons, Indian tribes confront one another in order to establish which of them is the most prestigious one. They hunt for very high stakes: Buffaloes, Tipis, Horses and the Sacred Totem. The player who will play their own Hunter and Hero cards clever and with skillfulness will be the winner…with Manitou’s help!

Based on Manitou.
19591.name: Big Manitou

19592.name: Winner's Circle
19592.description:
Each player is dealt a "Program" card that specifies a colored horse pawn and the betting odds for that horse. Each player is also dealt four movement cards. Based on the strength of those movement cards, each player places bets on his horse. Bets can be to Win, Place or Show on a player's own horse. The players have the option to place a Daily Double bet, which in this game is betting that the player's own horse will win the first two races. The players, one at a time, play a movement card. Most of the movement cards specify a number of spaces to move the player's horse pawn. Some of the movement cards state, "Ask Jockey". "Ask Jockey" means that the player turns over the top card of the "Ask Jockey" deck. The Ask Jockey cards are marked on their backs with a blue dot if the card has advantages for the player, red dot for disadvantages for the player, question marks ?? for instructions that may or may not affect the player that plays it. Holding an Ask Jockey card until that deck has a card with a blue dot on top is ideal. After the players have put into play and discarded all of the cards dealt, the entire movement deck is shuffled and four more cards are dealt to each player. "Ask Jockey" cards can require a player to give a number of his movement cards to another player or just discard them without using them. Therefore, players may use more or less than four movement cards per hand dealt. After the second race is complete, the Program cards are shuffled and dealt for each race. The race track board is proportionally marked for all of the common lengths of horse races. A game is complete after an agreed upon number of races and the instructions recommend 8 races. The most money wins.

This is NOT Knizia's Winner's Circle

19593.description:
This is the first in a series of 4 games in the Egypt to Canaan Hebron series of bible games published by Good Reading Limited in the 1970s.

Like the other games in the series it is a roll-and-move game and uses a D8 which it calls a 'Pyragon'.

From the rules:
"These exciting games have been carefully planned so as to give a constructive idea of the history of Israel from Bible, from the time of the captivity in Egypt up till the time of the settlement in the land God had promised them."
19593.name: Egypt to Canaan No.1 The Plagues of Egypt

19594.name: Egypt to Canaan No.2 The Wilderness Wandering
19594.description:
This is the second in a series of 4 games in the Egypt to Canaan Hebron series of bible games published by Good Reading Limited.

Like the other games in the series it is a roll-and-move game and uses a D8 which it calls a 'Pyragon'.

Players try to get their Cloud and Israel markers to Sinai.

From the rules:
"These exciting games have been carefully planned so as to give a constructive idea of the history of Israel from Bible, from the time of the captivity in Egypt up till the time of the settlement in the land God had promised them."

19595.name: Egypt to Canaan No.4 The Conquest of Canaan
19595.description:
This is the fourth in a series of 4 games in the Egypt to Canaan Hebron series of bible games published by Good Reading Limited.

Like the other games in the series it is a roll-and-move game and uses a D8 which it calls a 'Pyragon'.

Players race to encircle Jericho seven times to conquer it, capture Ai, capture five kings and move round twelve tribes.

From the rules:
"These exciting games have been carefully planned so as to give a constructive idea of the history of Israel from Bible, from the time of the captivity in Egypt up till the time of the settlement in the land God had promised them."

19596.name: Stoner Trivia, A Card Game
19596.description:
Well, it's finally here, a game devoted to marijuana trivia. Answer questions about Stoner movies, Music, History, Paraphernalia, Law, Medicine, Sports, Television, Unjust Bust, World culture, Horticulture, and more. These questions will leave you and your friends chatting for hours!

Stoner Trivia is a fun, novelty card game that tests your knowledge about marijuana and the stoner culture.

Each Stoner Trivia Card has a point value of +2, +3, +5, or 10 points which determines the difficulty of the question. Answer questions correctly to build up points to trade in for DOOBIE Cards. Collect 4-20 point DOOBIE Cards and win the game!

This game includes 350 Stoner Trivia™ questions, 25 DOOBIE Cards, 20 BUZZ Cards, 10 BUSTED Cards, 15 HAPPY TOKING Cards and a set of game direction

19597.name: Paddington
19597.description:
This children's card game contains 36 cards (9 different sets of 4 cards) depicting Paddington Bear from the BBC's 1970's children's TV series.

Cards are shuffled and dealt 5 to a player. The remaining cards form the draw pile, and the top card is turned over to start the discard pile.

On a player's turn, he may take the top card from either the draw pile or the discard pile. He then discards a card.

Each player aims to collect two sets - one of 3 cards and a pair. When a player completes a set during his turn, he places it face up on the table in front of him. The first player to lay both sets on the table is the winner.

19598.name: Period Pieces
19598.description:
This card game was published for the (British) National Trust by Dinosaur Publications.

The game comprises a set of 48 cards, 44 of which depict different furnishings from the Jacobean, Georgian, Victorian and Modern periods. The other 4 are 'House' cards, and they are used as Jokers which can be substituted for any other card.

The object of the game is to collect two sets of 3 or 4 object cards of the same period (e.g. Jacobean) or 3 or 4 object cards of the same type (e.g. lighting). The sets are:

1. Kettles
2. Tables
3. Clocks
4. Chairs
5. Toys
6. Cradles
7. Cabinets
8. Lighting
9. Musical Instruments
10. Irons
11. Vessels

PLAY
Seven cards are dealt to each player, the rest are turned face down to form the draw pile, with the top card being turned face up to start the discard pile. Each player in turn draws the top card from either the draw pile or the discard pile. He then discards a card. As a player collects a set of 3 cards he may, if he wishes, place them face upwards on the table in front of him and score their total. Any player having the fourth card to the set may, in turn, place it in front of himself and score its number. The game ends when one player has disposed of all the cards in his hand.

SCORING
Cards score according to the numbers on them. House cards score 20. All cards still in the hand of a player score against him, and all cards on the table score for the player who has collected them. The first player to score 200 points is the winner.

19599.name: Batter Up Baseball Card Game
19599.description:
Batter Up is a Baseball card game (using the rules of baseball) consisting of 36 cards and a fold out paper "field" depicting the Baseball diamond. The cards are:

BALL (x11)
FLY OUT (x2)
STRIKE (x10)
FOUL BALL (x2)
STOLEN BASE (x1)
OUT (x3)
SINGLE (x3)
DOUBLE (x2)
TRIPLE (x1)
HOME RUN (x1)

The first player at bat shuffles the cards, turning over 1 card at a time, until he gets a hit or an out. If he gets a hit, he places the card on the indicated base. The play is carried on as in an actual baseball game. When 3 outs are made, the playing side is retired. The opposing team comes to bat and the cards are reshuffled.

Special rules can be made. For example, it is optional to advance all base runners one extra base on a single and a double. This game may also be played as a party game where players take positions on bases.

A record of the balls, strikes and outs may be kept by a member of the opposing team calling out each card as it is turned over.

boardgamehonor: 2006 Deutscher Spiele Preis Best Family/Adult Game 3rd Place
2006 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee
2006 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player Nominee
2006 Tric Trac de Bronze
2006 Tric Trac Nominee
19600.description:
From the publisher's website:
Antike is a challenging strategy game about evolution and competition among ancient civilizations. Ancient nations create cities, build temples, sail the seas, and discover new principles of science and technology. Their legions and galleys open new settlements and defend their people against attacks from their enemies. Two scenarios can be chosen as the game board is two-sided. Players choose from Greeks, Romans, and Germanic tribes and Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Persians, Arabs, Egyptians, and Babylonians.

Every nation tries to win ancient kings, scholars, generals, citizens, and navigators for themselves. The nation that acquires a specified number (depending on the number of players) of ancient personalities first will win the game!

Lead one of these nations to victory! But watch out for your enemies, as they will want to conquer your cities to destroy your temples. The game depends not on the luck of dice or cards, but on thoughtful plans and skillful diplomacy.
boardgameversion: PD-Verlag Second edition with English rules
19600.name: Antike
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGWS 012 – Antike
Episode 004
German Gaming News #12
The Messy Game Room Episode 6
제105회 게임 대 게임 - 론델 시스템

19601.name: Metal Mental Meltdown
19601.description:
"The world's first heavy metal trivia board game."

Metal Mental Meltdown features questions that cover ALL genres of metal, from the NWOBHM to the gutters of the L.A. Glam scene to the snowy shores of the Scandinavian Black Metal invasion. There are thousands of questions about hundreds of bands and performers from the 70's, 80's and 90's. The questions are divided into four challenging categories: Head Bangers (fairly easy), Cranium Crackers (medium), Skull Krushers (hard) and Mental Meltdown (insanely hard!).

19602.name: Let's Play Golf
19602.description: Let's Play Golf is a card game for 2-12 players. The golfers compete to see who can achieve the lowest score by matching cards. The game requires a good memory and who ever can manage their hand best will putt their way to the lowest score.

19603.name: Profit
19603.description: Basically a Roll and Move game about - you might have guessed - making the most profit. Buy and sell goods, upgrade your ship to an airplane, build warehouses etc. Game ends when one player runs out of money.

19605.name: Death Test 2
19605.description:
Death Test 2 was MicroQuest #2 in the Metagaming MicroQuests series, programmed adventures for Melee and Wizard.

Sequel to Death Test, this paragraph-based adventure for the Melee/Wizard fantasy combat system recreates its predecessor's dungeon-crawl scenario but is significantly more difficult.

19606.name: Fear Factor Game
19606.description:
First saw this game at Universal Studios Florida and have now seen it showing up around the net stores.

You roll the dice to match the correct color combination on the stunt card faster than your opponent. Smash the spider (making it squeak) to win that round and move ahead! The first to make it from the Start space to the $50,000 winner space wins the game!

Cards have images taken directly from the TV show. Stunts are NOT performed, just read from cards. Game includes plastic bug shaped pieces and a black vinyl squeaking spider.

19608.name: Oraïa
19608.description:
The game is based in the 4 elements: water, air, earth and fire.
Each player choose one color and put his tokens in the starting places. Each player make alternate moves with his tokens.
The winner is the player who manage to move his tokens to the opponent's starting places.

Home Page: http://www.oraia.com/

19609.name: Crossfire Bingo
19609.description:
Crossfire Bingo - alternative to Bingo but make your own luck.
Each player has there own crossfire board and about 25 counters for covering the spaces.
Players take turns to roll the dice and cover a space or spaces on the board according to the numbers showing.
Example a a three and a five are showing
Options 1 cover the space 8 (by adding the dice together
2) Cover 3 and 5
3) Cover space 35
4) Cover space 53
To win the game you must have two rows of seven numbered spaces covered (D spaces included) with one row running vertically and the other row horizontally.

19610.name: PersonaliTease
19610.description:
From the back of the box:

"This is a party game... not a board game.

You don't have to sit around a table in uncomfortable chairs so you can just sit back and relax.
